perturbation.original_text:
Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. ("CCGI") and Pivotal Self Service Tech, Inc.
("PVSS"), (the "Parties" or "Joint Venturers" if referred to collectively, or
the "Party" or Joint Venturer" if referred to singularly), by this Agreement
associate themselves as business associates, and not as partners, in the
formation of a joint venture (the "Joint Venture"), for the purpose of engaging
generally in the business provided for by terms and provisions of this
Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text:
Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. ("CCGI") and Pivotal Self Service Tech, Inc.
("PVSS"), (the "Parties" or "Joint Venturers" if referred to collectively, or
the "Party" or Joint Venturer" if referred to singularly), by this Agreement
associate themselves as business associates, and also as partners, in the
formation of a joint venture (the "Joint Venture"), for the purpose of engaging
generally in the business provided for by terms and provisions of this
Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original text explicitly states that the parties are *not* associating as partners. The modified text creates a contradiction by stating they associate as both business associates and partners. This introduces ambiguity and contradicts the initial intent, potentially blurring the lines of liability and responsibility under partnership law, which could impact how the agreement is interpreted under Pennsylvania law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania Uniform Partnership Act, specifically regarding the definitions and implications of partnership versus other business associations.

perturbation.original_text:
5.	Powers and Authority of the Joint Venturers. The Joint Venturers shall have
full and complete charge of all affairs of the Joint Venture. The Joint
Venturers recognize that both of the Joint Venturers are and will continue
to be engaged in the conduct of their respective businesses for their own
account. Neither Joint Venturer shall be entitled to compensation for
services rendered to the Joint Venture as such, but each Joint Venturer
shall be reimbursed for all direct expenses, including travel, office, and
all other out-of-pocket expenses incurred in the operation of the affairs
of the Joint Venture and the promotion of its businesses.
perturbation.changed_text:
5.	Powers and Authority of the Joint Venturers. The Joint Venturers shall have
limited charge of all affairs of the Joint Venture. The Joint
Venturers recognize that both of the Joint Venturers are and will continue
to be engaged in the conduct of their respective businesses for their own
account. Neither Joint Venturer shall be entitled to compensation for
services rendered to the Joint Venture as such, but each Joint Venturer
shall be reimbursed for all direct expenses, including travel, office, and
all other out-of-pocket expenses incurred in the operation of the affairs
of the Joint Venture and the promotion of its businesses.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "full and complete charge" to "limited charge" without specifying the limitations introduces ambiguity. This contradicts the initial grant of authority and creates uncertainty regarding the scope of each venturer's power. Without clear definitions of the limitations, disputes could arise, making enforcement unpredictable under contract law. This is a contradiction because the contract states they have complete charge, then takes it back without outlining the limits.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding clarity and definiteness of terms; Pennsylvania contract law regarding authority and agency.

perturbation.original_text:
10.	Internal Revenue Code Election. The Joint Venturers agree and declare that
this association for the carrying on of a joint venture business operation
does not, and is not intended to create a partnership, for either legal or
United States income tax purposes, each Party recognizing that the other is
willing and able to contribute capital, labor, and services for the
operation of a successful joint venture business.
perturbation.changed_text:
10.	Internal Revenue Code Election. The Joint Venturers agree and declare that
this association for the carrying on of a joint venture business operation
does, and is intended to create a partnership, for either legal or
United States income tax purposes, each Party recognizing that the other is
willing and able to contribute capital, labor, and services for the
operation of a successful joint venture business.
perturbation.explanation: The original text explicitly states that the joint venture is *not* intended to create a partnership for tax purposes. The modified text completely reverses this declaration, stating it *is* intended to create a partnership for tax purposes. This directly contradicts the parties' stated intent regarding their tax treatment, creating a significant legal contradiction with implications under federal tax law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Section 761(a) of the Internal Revenue Code regarding election out of partnership status; partnership tax laws under Subchapter K of Chapter 1 of Subtitle A of the Code.
